properties.title: Post Incident Review (PIR) - Azure Automation delays and failures in East US 2
properties.description:
What happened?

Between 07:30 and 08:45 UTC on 01 November 2024, a platform issue resulted in an impact to the Azure Automation service in the East US 2 region. Impacted customers may have experienced delays in their job start or jobs falling into suspended state (including Update Management jobs).

What went wrong and why?

We have determined that an ongoing configuration change impacted instances of a backend service upon which Azure Automation relies, which led to the above-mentioned experience.

How did we respond?

  • 07:30 UTC on 01 November 2024 – Internal monitoring thresholds were breached, alerting us to this issue and prompting us to start our investigation.
  • 08:05 UTC on 01 November 2024 – We determined that a recent configuration change impacted instances of a backend service.
  • 08:20 UTC on 01 November 2024 – We started applying manual operations to bring the backend service back to a healthy state.
  • 08:45 UTC on 01 November 2024 – After a period of monitoring to validate the mitigation, we were confident that service functionality had been restored and no further impact was observed.

What happens next?

  • This Mitigation Statement is the final communication for this incident. For details about which Azure incidents qualify for which Post Incident Reviews (PIRs), refer to https://aka.ms/AzurePIRs.
  • The impact times above represent the full incident duration, so are not specific to any individual customer. Actual impact to service availability may vary between customers and resources – for guidance on implementing monitoring to understand granular impact: https://aka.ms/AzPIR/Monitoring.
  • To stay informed about future Azure service issues, make sure that you configure and maintain Azure Service Health alerts – these can trigger emails, SMS, push notifications, webhooks, and more: https://aka.ms/ash-alerts.
  • For broader guidance on preparing for cloud incidents, refer to https://aka.ms/incidentreadiness.

We were investigating an alert for Azure Automation in East US 2. This issue is now mitigated. We will provide more information shortly.

properties.title: Mitigated - Increased latency when retrieving platform logs while using diagnostic settings feature on Azure Monitor
properties.description:
What happened?

Between 01:50 UTC and 05:48 UTC on 29 October 2024, a platform issue resulted in an impact to the Azure Monitor service in the East US region. Impacted customers who had configured Azure Monitor with diagnostic log analytics feature settings experienced increased latency when retrieving platform logs and delayed alerts being fired

What do we know so far?

We determined that an unexpected spike in data volume being sent to backend service resources caused the delays and affected the performance of the service.

How did we respond?

  • 01:50 UTC on 29 October 2024 – Customer impact began.
  • 02:54 UTC on 29 October 2024 – Service monitoring detected increased latency in platform logs retrieval.
  • 03:13 UTC on 29 October 2024 – Identified the contributing cause as a spike in data volume being sent to backend services.
  • 03:23 UTC on 29 October 2024 – Initiated scaling out of resources to increase processing capacity.
  • 04:00 UTC on 29 October 2024 - Service performance observed to be improving, and latency decreasing.
  • 05:15 UTC on 29 October 2024 – Initiated the deployment of a hotfix to improve data processing prioritization.
  • 05:30 UTC on 29 October 2024 – Service performance confirmed to have returned to expected levels. 
  • 05:48 UTC on 29 October 2024 – Service health confirm to be restored, and customer impact mitigated.

What Happens Next?

  • Our team will be completing an internal retrospective to understand the incident in more detail. Once that is completed, generally within 14 days, we will publish a Post Incident Review (PIR) to all impacted customers.
  • To get notified when that happens, and/or to stay informed about future Azure service issues, make sure that you configure and maintain Azure Service Health alerts – these can trigger emails, SMS, push notifications, webhooks, and more: https://aka.ms/ash-alerts.
  • For more information on Post Incident Reviews, refer to https://aka.ms/AzurePIRs.
  • The impact times above represent the full incident duration, so are not specific to any individual customer. Actual impact to service availability may vary between customers and resources – for guidance on implementing monitoring to understand granular impact: https://aka.ms/AzPIR/Monitoring.
  • Finally, for broader guidance on preparing for cloud incidents, refer to https://aka.ms/incidentreadiness
properties.header: Your service might have been impacted by an Azure service issue

updates.summary:
What happened?

Between 01:50 UTC and 05:48 UTC on 29 October 2024, a platform issue resulted in an impact to the Azure Monitor service in the East US region. Impacted customers who had configured Azure Monitor with diagnostic log analytics feature settings experienced increased latency when retrieving platform logs and delayed alerts being fired

What do we know so far?

We determined that an unexpected spike in data volume being sent to backend service resources caused the delays and affected the performance of the service.

How did we respond?

  • 01:50 UTC on 29 October 2024 – Customer impact began.
  • 02:54 UTC on 29 October 2024 – Service monitoring detected increased latency in platform logs retrieval.
  • 03:13 UTC on 29 October 2024 – Identified the contributing cause as a spike in data volume being sent to backend services.
  • 03:23 UTC on 29 October 2024 – Initiated scaling out of resources to increase processing capacity.
  • 04:00 UTC on 29 October 2024 - Service performance observed to be improving, and latency decreasing.
  • 05:15 UTC on 29 October 2024 – Initiated the deployment of a hotfix to improve data processing prioritization.
  • 05:30 UTC on 29 October 2024 – Service performance confirmed to have returned to expected levels. 
  • 05:48 UTC on 29 October 2024 – Service health confirm to be restored, and customer impact mitigated.

What Happens Next?

  • Our team will be completing an internal retrospective to understand the incident in more detail. Once that is completed, generally within 14 days, we will publish a Post Incident Review (PIR) to all impacted customers.
  • To get notified when that happens, and/or to stay informed about future Azure service issues, make sure that you configure and maintain Azure Service Health alerts – these can trigger emails, SMS, push notifications, webhooks, and more: https://aka.ms/ash-alerts.
  • For more information on Post Incident Reviews, refer to https://aka.ms/AzurePIRs.
  • The impact times above represent the full incident duration, so are not specific to any individual customer. Actual impact to service availability may vary between customers and resources – for guidance on implementing monitoring to understand granular impact: https://aka.ms/AzPIR/Monitoring.
  • Finally, for broader guidance on preparing for cloud incidents, refer to https://aka.ms/incidentreadiness

Summary of Impact: Starting at 01:50 UTC on 29 Oct 2024, you have been identified as a customer who has configured Azure Monitor with diagnostic log analytics feature settings, in East US, may experience increased latency when retrieving platform logs. Customers who have configured alerts may also experience delayed alerts being fired.


Current Status: We have identified the root cause of the issue as an unexpected spike of data volume being sent to backend service resources for processing, leading to the impact mentioned above. We are currently scaling out resources in order to mitigate this issue. We are continuing to monitor telemetry to ensure the service is recovering as expected.


More information will be provided in 60 minutes, or as events warrant.

Summary of Impact: Starting at 01:50 UTC on 29 Oct 2024, customers using the diagnostic settings feature on their storage accounts in East US may be experiencing increased latency when retrieving platform logs.


Current Status: We are aware of the issue and are currently investigating the root cause. We will provide more information in 60 minutes, or as events warrant.

properties.title: Mitigated – Storage Metrics UI Regression Impacting Non-Classic Storage Accounts in Azure Monitor
properties.description:
What happened?

Between 00:00 UTC on 01 October 2024 and 06:01 UTC on 10 October 2024, you were identified as a customer using saved charts or the Insights blade for storage account (non-classic) metrics in Azure Monitor, who may have been unable to load certain charts or insights referring to specific storage metrics namespaces (blob, file, queues, table). If you were using the Metrics blade, you may not be able to see the namespaces until you select the specific storage sub-resource (blob, file, queue, table) corresponding to these metric namespaces. This impacts only non-classic storage accounts and does not affect account-level metrics or other resource types.

 

What do we know so far?

We determined that this issue was caused due to a code regression in the Azure Metrics chart control resulting in failures for these specifics type of Storage metrics when queried from the Azure Portal. 

 

How did we respond?

  • Previously by 16:46 UTC on 26 September 2024 - Rollout of the regression started.
  • 00:00 UTC on 01 October 2024 - Customer impact began. 
  • 00:05 UTC on 01 October 2024 - Our internal service monitoring detected failure rates going above the defined thresholds, and we started collaborating with additional teams to devise a mitigation solution and to find a root cause.
  • Approximately by 18:00 UTC on 08 October 2024 - The contributing factors of this issue were identified to be a code regression, and we started to identify and start deploying the hotfix to the regions affected by this outage. There were multiple regions affected globally, and this took us some time. Initially, this started with an investigation of another issue caused by the change of code regression post which we associated that root cause to this issue.
  • Furthermore, after recognizing the root cause, approximately by 20:00 UTC on 08 October 2024- Mitigation workstream started by applying a hotfix to all the regions globally. To all the regions, the deployment was successfully deployed except France Central.
  • 05:10 UTC on 10 October 2024 – The failing region was excluded from serving traffic to ensure the fix was provided to all users.
  • 05:55 UTC on 10 October 2024- We concluded that service operations were restored upon the next refresh of the portal.
  • 06:01 UTC on 10 October 2024- The issue was declared mitigated after further monitoring, and full-service functionality was restored.


What happens next?

  • Our team will be completing an internal retrospective to understand the incident in more detail. Once that is completed, generally within 14 days, we will publish a Post Incident Review (PIR) to all impacted customers.
  • To get notified when that happens, and/or to stay informed about future Azure service issues, make sure that you configure and maintain Azure Service Health alerts – these can trigger emails, SMS, push notifications, webhooks, and more: https://aka.ms/ash-alerts.
  • For more information on Post Incident Reviews, refer to https://aka.ms/AzurePIRs.
  • The impact times above represent the full incident duration, so are not specific to any individual customer. Actual impact to service availability may vary between customers and resources – for guidance on implementing monitoring to understand granular impact: https://aka.ms/AzPIR/Monitoring
  • Finally, for broader guidance on preparing for cloud incidents, refer to https://aka.ms/incidentreadiness.
properties.header: Your service might have been impacted by an Azure service issue

updates.summary:
What happened?

Between 00:00 UTC on 01 October 2024 and 06:01 UTC on 10 October 2024, you were identified as a customer using saved charts or the Insights blade for storage account (non-classic) metrics in Azure Monitor, who may have been unable to load certain charts or insights referring to specific storage metrics namespaces (blob, file, queues, table). If you were using the Metrics blade, you may not be able to see the namespaces until you select the specific storage sub-resource (blob, file, queue, table) corresponding to these metric namespaces. This impacts only non-classic storage accounts and does not affect account-level metrics or other resource types.

 

What do we know so far?

We determined that this issue was caused due to a code regression in the Azure Metrics chart control resulting in failures for these specifics type of Storage metrics when queried from the Azure Portal. 

 

How did we respond?

  • Previously by 16:46 UTC on 26 September 2024 - Rollout of the regression started.
  • 00:00 UTC on 01 October 2024 - Customer impact began. 
  • 00:05 UTC on 01 October 2024 - Our internal service monitoring detected failure rates going above the defined thresholds, and we started collaborating with additional teams to devise a mitigation solution and to find a root cause.
  • Approximately by 18:00 UTC on 08 October 2024 - The contributing factors of this issue were identified to be a code regression, and we started to identify and start deploying the hotfix to the regions affected by this outage. There were multiple regions affected globally, and this took us some time. Initially, this started with an investigation of another issue caused by the change of code regression post which we associated that root cause to this issue.
  • Furthermore, after recognizing the root cause, approximately by 20:00 UTC on 08 October 2024- Mitigation workstream started by applying a hotfix to all the regions globally. To all the regions, the deployment was successfully deployed except France Central.
  • 05:10 UTC on 10 October 2024 – The failing region was excluded from serving traffic to ensure the fix was provided to all users.
  • 05:55 UTC on 10 October 2024- We concluded that service operations were restored upon the next refresh of the portal.
  • 06:01 UTC on 10 October 2024- The issue was declared mitigated after further monitoring, and full-service functionality was restored.


What happens next?

  • Our team will be completing an internal retrospective to understand the incident in more detail. Once that is completed, generally within 14 days, we will publish a Post Incident Review (PIR) to all impacted customers.
  • To get notified when that happens, and/or to stay informed about future Azure service issues, make sure that you configure and maintain Azure Service Health alerts – these can trigger emails, SMS, push notifications, webhooks, and more: https://aka.ms/ash-alerts.
  • For more information on Post Incident Reviews, refer to https://aka.ms/AzurePIRs.
  • The impact times above represent the full incident duration, so are not specific to any individual customer. Actual impact to service availability may vary between customers and resources – for guidance on implementing monitoring to understand granular impact: https://aka.ms/AzPIR/Monitoring
  • Finally, for broader guidance on preparing for cloud incidents, refer to https://aka.ms/incidentreadiness.

Impact Statement: Starting at 00:00 UTC on Oct 01 2024, you have been identified as a customer using saved charts or the Insights blade for storage account (non-classic) metrics in Azure Monitor, who may have been unable to load certain charts or insights referring to specific storage metrics namespaces (blob, file, queues, table). If you are using the Metrics blade, you will not see these namespaces until you select the specific storage sub-resource (blob, file, queue, table) corresponding to these metric namespaces. This impacts only non-classic storage accounts and does not affect account-level metrics or other resource types.


Workaround:

  • If using the Metrics blade, please select the specific storage sub-resource (blob, table, queue, file) to view its corresponding metric namespaces.
  • If using a saved chart or Azure Portal-provided insights, update the resource selection in the metric query to the specific sub-resource to view your metrics. You do not need to save the revised query, as a mitigation is being rolled out to revert to previous behavior.


Current Status: We have started deploying a hotfix to address an issue affecting the visibility of certain storage metrics namespaces in Azure Monitor. Our teams are working to restore previous behavior as quickly as possible and minimize any impact to you. We will provide an update within the next 12 hours, or as events warrant.

Impact Statement: Starting at 00:00 UTC on Oct 01 2024, you have been identified as a customer using saved charts or the Insights blade for storage account (non-classic) metrics in Azure Monitor, who may have been unable to load certain charts or insights referring to specific storage metrics namespaces (blob, file, queues, table). If you are using the Metrics blade, you will not see these namespaces until you select the specific storage sub-resource (blob, file, queue, table) corresponding to these metric namespaces. This impacts only non-classic storage accounts and does not affect account-level metrics or other resource types.


Workaround:

  • If using the Metrics blade, please select the specific storage sub-resource (blob, table, queue, file) to view its corresponding metric namespaces.
  • If using a saved chart or Azure Portal-provided insights, update the resource selection in the metric query to the specific sub-resource to view your metrics. You do not need to save the revised query, as a mitigation is being rolled out to revert to previous behavior.


Current Status: We are actively investigating the issue with the involvement of multiple teams and are currently working on rolling out a hotfix to address this UI regression. The hotfix rollout is in progress to restore previous behavior, and we are focused on minimizing customer impact. The next update will be provided within 4 hours, or sooner if warranted.
